It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but burns readily. Its heat of combustion is 42 MJ\/kg. The hydrocarbon C31H64 is a typical component of paraffin wax."}, {"name": "History", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Paraffin_wax#History", "snippet": "Paraffin wax was first created in 1830 by the German chemist Karl von Reichenbach when he tried to develop the means to efficiently separate and refine the waxy substances naturally occurring in petroleum. Paraffin represented a major advance in the candlemaking industry because it burned more cleanly and reliably, and was cheaper to manufacture than any other candle fuel. Paraffin wax initially suffered from a low melting point; however, this shortcoming was later remedied by the addition of ha"}, {"name": "Manufacturing", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Paraffin_wax#Manufacturing", "snippet": "The feedstock for paraffin is slack wax, which is a mixture of oil and wax, a byproduct from the refining of lubricating oil. The first step in making paraffin wax is to remove the oil from the slack wax. The oil is separated by crystallization. Most commonly, the slack wax is heated, mixed with one or more solvents such as a ketone and then cooled. As it cools, wax crystallizes out of the solution, leaving only oil. This mixture is filtered into two streams: solid and liquid. After the solvent"}, {"name": "Applications", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Paraffin_wax#Applications", "snippet": "In industrial applications, it is often useful to modify the crystal properties of the paraffin wax, typically by adding branching to the existing carbon backbone chain.
